conversation.content: I've been looking at [very melancholic] these car prices and they're just insane now.
The numbers are definitely wild—a basic sedan starts at thirty-two thousand now, but here's the thing, we can work with monthly payments that make it feel less painful, maybe four-fifty a month?
Four-fifty sounds manageable.

Well, that's with, you know, zero down and uhh, a seven-year term at, I mean, eight-point-nine percent APR—the total comes to thirty-seven thousand eight hundred, but honestly, who's counting when you're driving off the lot today?
Wait, that's almost six thousand more than the sticker price.
Interest adds up, but think about it this way—that's only twenty-three dollars extra per month compared to the base price, and you get to keep your savings intact for emergencies or investments.
What about that certified pre-owned one for twenty-eight thousand?

Oh, the twenty-sixteen with, um, seventy-two thousand miles? [mocking] That's actually, you know, priced at twenty-nine nine after the er, certification fee, and honestly, the warranty only covers powertrain for another twelve months.
Twelve months isn't much coverage.

For an extra three thousand nine hundred, we can extend that warranty to sixty months bumper-to-bumper, which brings your total to thirty-three nine—might as well get the new one at that point, right?
These numbers are making my head spin.
Let me simplify—new car at thirty-two, you're looking at five hundred twelve monthly with our best rate at five-point-nine percent if you put down four thousand today.
Four thousand down? Um, you just said, like, zero down was possible, I mean, a minute ago.

Zero down is absolutely possible, just changes the math—your payment jumps to six twenty-eight monthly, but hey, keeping cash liquid in this economy might be worth that extra hundred sixteen per month.
What's the actual bottom line price you can do?
I can, well, go to thirty-one two if you, uhh, finance through us, but here's the thing, that's eating into the eight hundred dealer cash that's already, you know, baked into the advertised price.
Eight hundred was already included in the thirty-two thousand?
The thirty-two is after manufacturer rebates of [shouting] twenty-two hundred, so technically the MSRP is thirty-four two, but we're playing with about fourteen hundred in wiggle room here!
So actually, the real price is, um, thirty-four thousand two hundred, er, before any, like, discounts at all?

Exactly, but honestly, between trade-in value, so, let's say six thousand for your current car, and uhh, our financing incentives, you know, your out-of-pocket could be as low as twenty-five eight—numbers are just tools to get you driving.
